Being from a lower  branch on the evolutionary tree, Slugs are closer to the first lifeforms on this planet then many give them credit for. Soft bodied creatures who probably were more translucent like deeper sea slugs and many fish of the deep didnt really have use for eyes and developed light sensitive cells in the brain as a way to avoid danger from volcanic events and light emitting predators. and to find mates who probably could translucence  themselves at a specific wavelength. The evolution of eyes as we know them became far more necessary as life began to swim and the evolutionary arms race that was the Cambrian took off.

If I remember it correctly then the retina of the vertebrate eyes is an outgrowth from the brain, not a remotely developed organ that then is wired up to the brains visual processing centers. Our eyes have two origins, one part an ingrowth from the outer layer of embryo forming most of the eye, and another part that grows from the developing brain and forms the optic nerve and the retina. I guess the brain also originates from the outer layer. The "tube" that becomes the medulla is an involution from the outer layer too.
